acf.stories_intro: Discover the stories behind the project. From how Project Jetson was born, to failures and fortunes and missteps in experimentation, and meeting the people behind the process – explore the stories and insights section for a look behind the scenes.

sections.title: Project Jetson
sections.text:
UNHCR’s Innovation Service has been working to understand the intrinsic nexus between climate change, violent conflict, and forced displacement. Using supervised machine learning, UNHCR designed Project Jetson, an engine that is fed data and uses trained models to predict the displacement of persons in Somalia.

Forced displacement is a complex phenomenon. Mathematical evidence shows that there are certain factors, such as food insecurity and violent conflict, as well as the appeal of the destination region, in terms of price, distance, and stability, that cause people to move. Certain combinations of these factors are more likely to make people move than others.

Project Jetson is an on-going experiment to discover, understand, and measure the specific factors that cause, indicate or exacerbate the forced displacement of Somalis.

Project Jetson gives UNHCR and other humanitarian organizations the potential to become more proactive in their response efforts — a transformation that could significantly improve on-the-ground relief services and more importantly the lives of those who are forcibly displaced.

sections.title: Success Metrics
sections.text:
For a project like this, we develop a strategic vision document aimed to create some metrics of success of the project.  The goals are aligned to UNHCR Innovation work: 1) research new methods, 2) facilitate and foster collaboration and organizational culture around innovation and 3) improve tools that create awareness of decision-making processes with data to improve protection outcomes.

The following metrics of success have been developed to evaluate the overall performance of the project:

  • Solve the challenge given by a UNHCR field operation: predict the number of arrivals, both IDPs and refugees in certain regions of Somalia and the cross-border south region of Ethiopia (Dollo Ado)
  • Improve research on predictive analytics for protection purposes in the humanitarian space
  • Develop a methodology and its related tools for forced displacement predictions.
  • Predict in advance, with a certain degree of accuracy, the number of arrivals in a determined location
  • And last but not least, understanding the linkages between machines and human decision making in the humanitarian space.
